Award.AwardTitle: Using Radio Pulsars to Probe Gravity, Dark Matter, and Stellar Populations in the Galactic Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an observational program to discover and characterize pulsars toward the center of the Milky Way galaxy. Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars, which are usually best detected at radio wavelengths because they emit regular pulsations from beamed emission that periodically sweeps across the Earth. The goal of the project is not to study pulsars or their radio emission, but rather to use pulsars as probes of the gravitational field in the galactic center. This group has already detected several radio pulsars in the galactic center region, and now wishes to undertake a careful survey to find more.

In the event that one or more can be found in physical proximity to the massive black hole at the galactic center, long-term positional and timing studies can provide valuable tests of general relativity and can detect the presence of optically invisible members of the central star cluster. The project will benefit from the participation and education of graduate students. This group will also work with the Pulsar Search Collaboratory, funded by NSF, which brings together pulsar researchers and high school/undergraduate students in the West Virginia area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the project was to probe the environment around the massive black hole in the center of the Milky Way galaxy that we live in.   To do so we conducted observations with several radio telescopes to find and study rotating neutron stars (pulsars) that can be used as superb measuring devices. They allow measurements to be made of the gas contents and magnetic field in the region and, most importantly, allos us to test Einstein's General Theory of Relativity and other theories of gravity.   The intellectual merit of the project therefore is in the spirit of exploration of an exotic region in our home galaxy while also testing fundamental physics.   The project involved intensive acquisition and analysis of large and complex data sets using the Very Large Array in New Mexico and other telescopes.  The project used a new mode of data acquisition that provided 10,000 samples per second over periods of hours. The data were searched for periodic signals from pulsars and also for individual bursts of radio emission that can be produced by neutron stars and other objects. Analysis of the data incorporated custom signal processing algorithms. Development of algorithms and software was done by students, one of whom is writing his PhD dissertation based on this project.  The skills developed are at the forefront of research in astrophysics and are transferable to other fields, both in the physical sciences and other areas.  The broader impact also includes the results from the project's focus on a high magnetic field pulsar very close to the central black hole.  This object allowed us to measure properties of the dense gas fairly close to the central black hole.  It also signifies the presence of a population of neutron stars and other stars, including stellar mass black holes.  However, we have not yet found additional pulsars, a fact that suggests that star formation proceeds quite differently than in the rest of our galaxy.   Researchers working in plasma astrophysics,  star formation, and imaging techniques have incorporated results of this aspect of the research.  We have discovered a few isolated bursts from unknown sources very near the central black hole.   We are in the process of assessing the kinds of astrophysical sources that might produce the bursts.  Continued work on the center of the galaxy is needed and it will surely provide results of interest to both specialists and the general public.
